Module MathUtils
Package mathUtils.calculus

Class Polynomial

java.lang.Object
mathUtils.calculus.Polynomial
public class Polynomial
extends java.lang.Object
This class represents a mathematical polynomial. It is expressed in form of:

\( P(x) = a_0x^0 + a_1x^1 + a_2x^2...+a_nx^n = \displaystyle\sum\limits_{k=0}^n a_kx^k \)

In other words, a polynomial is the sum of a set of coefficients and their powers. Here, each term of the polynomial is an instance of Polynomial.Term, all of which are elements of the List that is used to represent the polynomial.For example, to create a polynomial
\( P(x) = 2x^3 - 5x^2 + 9 \)
write:
Polynomial p = new Polynomial(9, 0, -5, 2)
Of course, you can use the implemented methods to change the structure of the polynomial.

  • Nested Class Summary

    Nested Classes
    Modifier and Type Class Description
    static class  Polynomial.Term
    This class represents a term of a polynomial.

  • Constructor Details

    • Polynomial

      public Polynomial()
      The default constructor. Creates a polynomial with no value.

    • Polynomial

      public Polynomial​(Polynomial.Term... terms)
      Creates a polynomial from the given terms. The given List contains the terms of the polynomial, which are then used to form one single polynomial.
      Parameters:
      terms - The List that represents the polynomial

    • Polynomial

      public Polynomial​(double... coefficients)
      Creates a polynomial from the given coefficients. The polynomial's exponents rise with the number of coefficients in ascending order. For example, the code new Polynomial(2, 0, 3) yields the polynomial \( 2x^0 + 0x^1 + 3x^2 \).
      Parameters:
      coefficients - The coefficients of the polynomial

    • Polynomial

      public Polynomial​(Polynomial p)
      Creates a polynomial by copying an existing polynomial.
      Parameters:
      p - The polynomial to copy

  • Method Details

    • fromPoints

      public static Polynomial fromPoints​(double[] x, double[] y)
      Calculates a polynomial from the given x-y-pairs. The function that is represented by this polynomial passes through all of the given points.
      Parameters:
      x - The x-coordinates
      y - The y-coordinates associated with the x-coordinates
      Returns:
      A polynomial that passes through the given points

    • fromPoints

      public static Polynomial fromPoints​(Point... points)
      Calculates a polynomial from the given points. The function that is represented by this polynomial passes through all of the given points. Note that the z-coordinate of the given points is ignored. Also, this method simply delegates to: Polynomial.fromPoints(x, y).
      Parameters:
      points - The points
      Returns:
      A polynomial that passes through the given points

    • fromFunction

      public static Polynomial fromFunction​(Function f, int degree)
      Calculates a polynomial from the given function. The polynomial passes through all of the function's extreme points and shares the function's global limits.
      Parameters:
      f - The function to create a polynomial from
      Returns:
      A polynomial that represents the given function

    • add

      public Polynomial add​(Polynomial.Term... terms)
      Adds a polynomial to this polynomial. The polynomial is defined by an array of Polynomial.Terms, whose sum represents the polynomial. The sum of both polynomials is then returned to efficiently allow the use of functional, stream-like operations.
      Parameters:
      terms - The polynomial to add
      Returns:
      The sum of both polynomials

      Adds a polynomial to this polynomial. The sum of both polynomials is then returned to efficiently allow the use of functional, stream-like operations.
      Parameters:
      p - The polynomial to add
      Returns:
      The sum of both polynomials

      public Polynomial subtract​(Polynomial.Term... terms)

      Parameters:
      terms - The polynomial to subtract
      Returns:
      The difference of both polynomials

      Returns:

    • pow

      public Polynomial pow​(double n)
      Calculates the power of this polynomial. After the calculations, this polynomial is returned as a result, so to allow functional, stream-like use of this class.
      Parameters:
      n - The exponent
      Returns:
      This polynomial raised to the given power

    • square

      public Polynomial square()
      Squares this polynomial. It is identical to: pow(2). After the calculations, this polynomial id returned as a result, so to allow functional, stream-like use of this class.
      Returns:
      The square of this polynomial

      public Polynomial sqrt()
      Calculates the square root of this polynomial. It is identical to: root(2).
      Returns:

      Returns:
      An array that represents this polynomial.

    • setTerms

      public void setTerms​(Polynomial.Term... terms)
      Overwrites the List that is used to store the polynomial. The current List and its elements are nullified.
      Parameters:
      terms - The array to overwrite the List with

    • put

      public void put​(int exponent, double coefficient)
      Associates the given exponent with the given coefficient.
      Parameters:
      exponent - The exponent (the n-th term)
      coefficient - The coefficient

    • put

      public void put​(double... coefficients)
      Adds the given coefficients to the polynomial. The polynomial's exponents rise with the number of coefficients in ascending order. For example, the code:

      Polynomial p = new Polynomial();
      p.put(2, 0, 3);

      yields the polynomial \( 2x^0 + 0x^1 + 3x^2 \).
      Parameters:
      coefficients - The coefficients of the polynomial

    • nullify

      public void nullify()
      Resets this polynomial to represents 0. All of the terms are therefore nullified. It is identical to clearing the List that is used to store the polynomial's terms.

    • removeTrivialTerms

      public void removeTrivialTerms()
      Removes all of the terms whose coefficients are 0.

    • getTermByCoefficient

      public Polynomial.Term getTermByCoefficient​(double coefficient)
      Retrieves the first term of this polynomial with the matching coefficient. If there is no term that has the given coefficient, then null is returned.
      Parameters:
      coefficient - The term's coefficient to search for
      Returns:
      The first term with the matching coefficient

    • getTermByExponent

      public Polynomial.Term getTermByExponent​(double exponent)
      Retrieves the term of this polynomial with the matching coefficient. If there is no non-zero term in this polynomial that has the given exponent, then null is returned.
      Parameters:
      exponent - The exponent to search for
      Returns:
      The term with the given exponent

    • getLeadingTerm

      public Polynomial.Term getLeadingTerm()
      Retrieves the leading term of this polynomial. It is the non-zero term of this polynomial with the greatest exponent. It also signifies this polynomial's degree. This method automatically orders this polynomial's terms in ascending order.
      Returns:
      The polynomial's leading term

    • getLowestTerm

      public Polynomial.Term getLowestTerm()
      Retrieves this polynomial's lowest term. It is the non-zero term of this polynomial with the smallest exponent. This method automatically sorts this polynomial's terms in ascending order.
      Returns:
      The polynomial's lowest term

    • degree

      public int degree()
      Calculates the degree (greatest exponent) of this polynomial. The degree is given by the non-zero term with the greatest exponent. This method also sorts the polynomial's terms.
      Returns:
      The degree of this polynomial

    • valueOf

      public double valueOf​(double x)
      Evaluates this polynomial at the given point x. Since a polynomial is nothing but the sum of its terms, this method uses each term's valueOf(x) method and adds them up to obtain this polynomial's value.
      Parameters:
      x - The point x
      Returns:
      The value of this polynomial at the given point x

    • toFunction

      public Function toFunction()
      Converts this polynomial to a Function. For each x, valueOf(x) of this polynomial is evaluated and then returned.

    • getOrderedTerms

      public Polynomial.Term[] getOrderedTerms()
      Returns an array of Polynomial.Terms whose sum represents this polynomial. The terms are ordered in ascending order, where the first element has the smallest exponent and the last element has the greatest one.
      Returns:
      An array that represents this polynomial

    • toString

      public java.lang.String toString()
      Returns a String that represents this polynomial. The polynomial's terms are ordered in descending order. Terms are parsed as: ax^n with their respective sign (+, -).
      Overrides:
      toString in class java.lang.Object
      Returns:
      A String that represents this polynomial

    • companionMatrix

      public Matrix companionMatrix()
      Calculates this polynomial's companion matrix. This matrix is expressed in form of:

      \( C(p) = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 0 & \cdots & 0 & -a_0 \\ 1 & 0 & \cdots & 0 & -a_1 \\ 0 & 1 & \cdots & 0 & -a_2 \\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots & \vdots \\ 0 & 0 & \cdots & 1 & -a_n \\ \end{bmatrix} \)

      Where each \( a \) is a coefficient.
      Returns:
      This polynomial's companion matrix

    • derivative

      public Polynomial derivative​(int n)
      Computes the n-th derivative of this polynomial. The derivative of a function \( f(x) \) indicates how fast the function increases at any given point \( x \). Here, each term in form of \( ax^n \) is computed as \( an \cdot x^{n-1} \), which is identical to the polynomial's derivative. Therefore, we can say that:
      \( P(x) = \displaystyle\sum\limits_{i=0}^{n} \dfrac{d}{dx}T_i(x) \)
      Where \( n \) is the number of terms in the polynomial.
      Parameters:
      n - The number of times to differentiate
      Returns:
      The n-th derivative of this polynomial

    • integral

      public Polynomial integral​(int n)
      Computes the n-th integral of this polynomial. The integral of a function \( f(x) \) indicates the area under the curve of the function from \( 0 \) to \( x \). Here, each term of the polynomial in form of \( ax^b \) is treated as \( \frac{a}{b+1}x^{b+1} \). The integral is given by the sum of all integrals of each term. Therefore, we can say that:
      \( P(x) = \displaystyle\sum\limits_{i=0}^n \displaystyle\int T_i(x)dx \), where \( n \) is the number of terms in the polynomial.
      Parameters:
      n - The number of times to integrate
      Returns:
      The n-th integral of this polynomial

    • integral

      public Polynomial integral()
      Computes the integral of this polynomial. The integral of a function \( f(x) \) indicates the area under the curve of the function from \( 0 \) to \( x \). Here, each term of the polynomial in form of \( ax^b \) is treated as \( \frac{a}{b+1}x^{b+1} \). The integral is given by the sum of all integrals of each term. Therefore, we can say that:
      \( P(x) = \displaystyle\sum\limits_{i=0}^n \displaystyle\int T_i(x)dx \), where \( n \) is the number of terms in the polynomial.
      Returns:
      The integral of this polynomial

    • derivative

      public Polynomial derivative()
      Computes the derivative of this polynomial. The derivative of a function \( f(x) \) indicates how fast the function increases at any given point \( x \). Here, each term in form of \( ax^n \) is computed as \( an \cdot x^{n-1} \), which is identical to the polynomial's derivative. Therefore, we can say that:
      \( P(x) = \displaystyle\sum\limits_{i=0}^{n} \dfrac{d}{dx}T_i(x) \)
      Where \( n \) is the number of terms in the polynomial.
      Returns:
      The derivative of this polynomial

    • integrate

      public double integrate​(double a, double b)
      Integrates this polynomial within the given bounds. The integral \( \int\limits_a^b P(x)dx \) is the area underneath the curve of \( P(x) \) from \( a \) to \( b \). It is identical to: \( I_P(b) - I_P(a) \), where \( I_P(x) \) is the integral of this polynomial.
      Parameters:
      a - The lower bound of the integral
      b - The upper bound of the integral
      Returns:
      The integral from a to b of this polynomial

    • arcLength

      public double arcLength​(double a, double b)
      Calculates this polynomial's arc's length within the given bounds. It uses the following formula:
      \( \displaystyle\int\limits_{a}^{b} \sqrt{1+ \left( \frac{dy}{dx} \right)^2}dx \)
      Parameters:
      a - The lower bound of the integral
      b - The upper bound of the integral
      Returns:
      This polynomial's arc's length from a to b

    • singleRoot

      public double singleRoot​(int error)
      Returns a single root of this polynomial. This method utilizes the Newton-Raphson Method, which states that:
      \( x_{i+1} = x_i - \dfrac{P(x_i)}{P'(x_i)} \)
      Where \( P(x) \) is this polynomial, \( P'(x) \) is this polynomial's derivative and \( x_i \) is a guessed root. Therefore, \( x_{i+1} \) becomes an always better approximation of this polynomial's root with each iteration of the algorithm.
      Parameters:
      error - How often to repeat the algorithm
      Returns:
      An approximation od one of this polynomial's roots

    • singleRoot

      public double singleRoot()
      Returns a single root of this polynomial. This method utilizes the Newton-Raphson Method, which states that:
      \( x_{i+1} = x_i - \dfrac{P(x_i)}{P'(x_i)} \)
      Where \( P(x) \) is this polynomial, \( P'(x) \) is this polynomial's derivative and \( x_i \) is a guessed root. Therefore, \( x_{i+1} \) becomes an always better approximation of this polynomial's root with each iteration of the algorithm. Note that this method simply delegates to singleRoot(1000), which should be accurate enough in most cases.
      Returns:
      An approximation od one of this polynomial's roots

    • polyRoots

      public double[] polyRoots​(int error)
      Finds all of the roots of this function. This method iteratively invokes singleRoot() (Newton-Raphson algorithm) to ultimately find all of the approximated roots. Let us say that we have a function \( f(x) \) whose roots we will call \( \Omega \). We now perform long-polynomial-division to define another function, \( g(x) \) whose roots are exactly those of \( f(x) \), except for the one root given by singleRoot():
      \( g(x) = \dfrac{f(x) - f(n)}{x - n} \; ; n \in \Omega \)
      Now we repeat this algorithm until \( g(x) \) becomes a degree-0 polynomial, i.e. a constant.
      Parameters:
      error - Parameter to parse in singleRoot(int error)
      Returns:
      An approximation of the zeros of this function

    • polyRoots

      public double[] polyRoots()
      Finds all of the roots of this function. This method iteratively invokes singleRoot() (Newton-Raphson algorithm) to ultimately find all of the approximated roots. Let us say that we have a function \( f(x) \) whose roots we will call \( \Omega \). We now perform long-polynomial-division to define another function, \( g(x) \) whose roots are exactly those of \( f(x) \), except for the one root given by singleRoot():
      \( g(x) = \dfrac{f(x) - f(n)}{x - n} \; ; n \in \Omega \)
      Now we repeat this algorithm until \( g(x) \) becomes a degree-0 polynomial, i.e. a constant. Note that this method simply delegates to polyRoots(1000), which should be accurate enough in most cases.
      Returns:
      An approximation of the zeros of this function
